citations.narrative:
An enclosure housing 2 adult red fox failed to protect the animals from injury. One fox in the enclosure, an approximately
5-year-old melanistic, female, red fox cut the skin in between the 2nd and 3rd toes on her right front paw. There is metal
sheeting used as partial flooring in the enclosure that has exposed sharp edges. The fox was noted by APHIS inspectors
to be holding the right front paw up and limping. The fox was also seen to be licking the right front paw. The other fox in
the enclosure had no observable injuries.
The licensee noted that the foxes have been digging a lot recently and she has been trying different ways of modifying the
enclosure to combat that. The licensee stated that the foxes and the enclosure were both fine the day before and she had
not yet observed the female fox to be limping as she had not finished all of her chores yet at the time of inspection.
The licensee added additional flooring to avoid any further injury during the inspection.
Enclosures with sharp points or edges can be a source of injury to the animals living within. Especially with a species
known for digging, it is important to construct housing enclosures in a manner that they are structurally sound, but also
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. Correct by: February 29, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure housing 2 adult red fox failed to protect the animals from injury. One fox in the enclosure, an approximately 
5-year-old melanistic, female, red fox cut the skin in between the 2nd and 3rd toes on her right front paw. There is metal 
sheeting used as partial flooring in the enclosure that has exposed sharp edges. The fox was noted by APHIS inspectors 
to be holding the right front paw up and limping. The fox was also seen to be licking the right front paw. The other fox in 
the enclosure had no observable injuries. 
 
The licensee noted that the foxes have been digging a lot recently and she has been trying different ways of modifying the 
enclosure to combat that. The licensee stated that the foxes and the enclosure were both fine the day before and she had 
not yet observed the female fox to be limping as she had not finished all of her chores yet at the time of inspection. 
 
The licensee added additional flooring to avoid any further injury during the inspection. 
 
Enclosures with sharp points or edges can be a source of injury to the animals living within. Especially with a species 
known for digging, it is important to construct housing enclosures in a manner that they are structurally sound, but also 
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. Correct by: February 29, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
